description:
Referred as "the mini Golondrinas", this is one of the most famous pits of Chiapas and has now been developed as a tourist attraction.

At the bottom is a small forest, a naturally protected summer nesting area for the sinkholeâ€™s namesake residents: thousands of cotorras, or green parrots. On the walls of the pit are several petroglyphs left by pre-mayan civilizations.

While Sima de las Cotorras is impressive any time, the best time to visit is March to October, when the parrots are most numerous.

There is a campsite and multiple cabins for rent next to the restaurant that owns the pit.

Approach

Drive to Ocozocoautla, then to Crucero San Luis, then to Piedra Parada. It is a bit hard to get to without a car. There are companies that offer this as a guided trip (including transportation) from San Cristobal.

Descent

The pit is a near perfect round sinkhole in the ground about 140 deep with a diameter of 160 meter. From roughly October till March groups of parrots fly out of the abyss in the morning, hence its name. You can rappel down into it, and see of pre-hispanic drawings on the walls.

It is rumored that killer bees nest in the walls of the pit, so if planning to drop the pit is better to go on colder days.

Exit

If you rappel all the way to the bottom you'll ascend out to the halway point. From there, it's a walk along the wall where you'll be able to see pre-Mayan pictographs.

Red tape

The only way to rappel Sima de las Cotorras is with the company that owns the land/restaurant. As of 2021, the price is 750 pesos for a rappel all the way to the bottom, or 550 pesos to rappel half way (and hike back out past the pictographs).
